A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Dihedral Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To understand whether the concept of a Set is necessary for the definition of a Dihedral Group, we need to analyze the components of the Dihedral Group definition:

1. The dihedral group $D_{n}$ is described as a group of symmetries of a regular $n$-gon. This implies a collection of elements (symmetries) which inherently forms a set.

2. The group is generated by permutations $\(\sigma\)$ and $	au$. Permutations are specific rearrangements of a set of objects, in this case, the vertices of the $n$-gon. Thus, the concept of permutations relies on the concept of a set.

3. A group in mathematical terms is a set equipped with a binary operation that satisfies certain axioms (closure, associativity, identity element, and inverses). Therefore, the very definition of a group presupposes the existence of a set.

From these points, it is clear that the concept of a Set is fundamental to the definition of a Dihedral Group. Without the concept of a Set, the notion of permutations, collections of symmetries, and the structure of a group itself would not be well-defined.
